Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An embedded and in-context professional learning platform for math problem-solving instruction
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project proposes to research and develop a web-based prototype that provides teachers with individualized, interactive, and timely supports for improving students? problem-solving skills and math communication. Despite the expectations placed on math teachers by the Common Core State Standards, most of them are insufficiently prepared to teach students how to become effective problem solvers. Research shows that the largest struggle for teachers is not learning new strategies to teaching but actually implementing them in the classroom. This project addresses this challenge by offering professional development that is embedded and ongoing and sets the stage for educators to develop essential 21st Century skills including critical thinking, communication, collaboration and creativity. These are essential job skills not only for educators but for the young minds they coach and mentor. Additionally, teachers who themselves approach problem solving with confidence and enthusiasm inspire students to do the same. This has great implications for how many students will continue to seek and enroll in STEM programs. The annual market for professional development is expected to grow to $1.8 to $2 billion dollars within 5 years just for math and science in K-12 schools, a significant market for this project to target.


The proposed project will result in a prototype that works seamlessly with the existing student-facing peer-to-peer application, developed by the same company and already in the marketplace. In order to achieve this level of embedded instruction, the project intends to build a sophisticated recommendation engine that not only analyzes the teacher's user profile but also their actions in using the student-facing platform and responds with suggested pathways to improve their teaching. This is a unique approach to professional development, enabling educators to determine how to introduce, instruct, and assess problem-solving skills in a sustained manner. This study is anchored in National Council on Teachers of Mathematics' (NCTM) "Principles to Actions: Ensuring Mathematical Success for All" and is designed to directly address three of their eight recommended essential practices and six of the specific recommended actions. The proposed project consists of a five-month iterative, formative evaluation-based development phase followed by a one-month pilot study where classroom teachers will evaluate the functional prototype.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CueTeach is a web-based application that works in conjunction with CueThink, a peer-to-peer application that leverages Pólya’s (1945) four-phase problem solving approach to improve elementary and secondary students’ critical thinking skills, math language, and communication. The intent of CueTeach is to provide teachers with individualized, interactive, and timely supports. The purpose of this NSF SBIR Phase I research study was to iteratively design and develop a CueTeach prototype and collect evidence of its usability and utility.

 

Despite the expectations placed on math teachers by the Common Core State Standards, most math teachers are insufficiently prepared to teach students how to become critical thinkers and problem solvers. During late elementary school years—a time when students’ problem solving skills are expected to be blossoming—students are found to be especially lacking in applying their mathematical knowledge to problems. This trend continues much into middle school, and by the time students reach high school, their math skills are woefully behind their counterparts in other countries. Much of this problem is due to the limited pedagogical skills of teachers in providing adequate problem solving instruction and supports—on top of teachers’ own limited problem solving skills. Compounding this problem is the fact that traditional processes for empowering teachers with content and pedagogy skills are of limited effectiveness (Glazerman et al, 2010).  The largest struggle for teachers is not learning new strategies and approaches to teaching but actually implementing them in the classroom; it takes, on average, twenty separate instances of practice in a real life setting, before a teacher has mastered complex skills.

 

CueTeach has been developed to address this problem. Built as an HTML 5 browser-based application, CueTeach use the data gleaned from CueThink as one of its inputs.  CueTeach’s interactive tools, timely resources and a virtual peer community are designed to enable teachers to foster critical thinking skills, develop a growth mindset, understand students’ thinking process and cull best approaches and strategies to inform their teaching. As such, the CueTeach platform will provide a more effective and efficient teacher training solution.

 

Formative evaluation of prototype iterations was conducted by providing participating teachers focus group- and interview-based demonstrations of the software and discussed impressions, issues, and subsequent design ideas. The participants ranged from those who were “running with” CueThink to those who were still learning it.

 

The second phase, pilot evaluation, occurred in the final month of the project when we asked CueThink-experienced teachers to use the CueTeach prototype and gathered evidence of its usability and efficacy, evaluated it vis-à-vis its theoretical approach, and set the stage for further research and development efforts.

 

Based on the formative evaluation phase findings, CueTeach prototype design and development efforts focused on three categories of features. Implementation of these sets of features was determined to satisfy the efficacy-based research questions posed at the start of the study. The three categories of features, and the features themselves, are:

  1. Tagging: Metadata for thinklets; filter the gallery list of thinklets by these tags
  2. Rubric: evaluate thinklets; view class data according to evaluations
  3. Reflections: enter reflection notes about problems; view reflections while selecting problems

 

During the pilot study, the cognitive lab analysis demonstrated that teachers’ use of CueTeach features was facile, purposeful, and in line with their design to support teachers’ math problem solving instruction. Focus groups demonstrated solid understanding of the intention of CueTeach features and belief that CueTeach would support CueThink use in the classroom and facilitate math problem solving instruction per the NCTM (2014) instructional planning and formative assessment practices. Finally, evidence from surveys demonstrated the extent to which each of the features in the three feature categories supports teachers’ instructional planning and formative assessment activities.

 

Our strongest dissemination path is that we are already selling CueTeach 1.0 to schools. When customers subscribe to CueThink, we are upselling them on CueTeach which several math administrators find especially useful. We also anticipate providing paid professional training to help schools maximize the use of CueTeach 1.0 as part of their purchase. As part of this project, we have also developed a Professional Learning Course, with the intent to package and sell the training course to pre-service and in-service teachers in Schools of Education. Finally, we have several articles in the works describing this new vision of embedded PD with CueTeach.

 

Our approach to empowering teachers to improve their own problem solving skills has the potential to offer unique solutions to several different markets. While we plan to start with math, we also see CueTeach being used in other STEM instruction, where the emphasis is on higher order thinking. Teacher education is yet another market to sell to, since teachers need training BEFORE they come into the classrooms, in addition to needing it on an ongoing basis while in the classrooms.
